title: DeVos details philosophy on ESSA waivers
content:
With help from Benjamin Wermund and Kimberly Hefling The Council of Chief State School Officers, in town for a conference, will hear from the leaders of the House and Senate education committees today. On Monday, Education Secretary Betsy DeVos encouraged the K-12 education chiefs to “continue to raise the bar."
— Former "Desperate Housewives" star Felicity Huffman apologized for her role in a sweeping admissions cheating and bribery scandal . She and 13 others will plead guilty, the Justice Department announced.
— A decade after the start of the Great Recession, state funding for higher education has only recovered halfway. That’s according to the latest report by the State Higher Education Executive Officers Association.
IT’S TUESDAY. Got news to share? Drop me a line at ngaudiano@politico.com .
Driving the Day TALKING K-12: The Education secretary took a more conciliatory tone with K-12 education chiefs on Monday, a year after taking them to task for the quality of their state plans under ESSA.
— DeVos told the Council of Chief State School Officers that her department would look favorably on requests for waivers designed to increase expectations for student achievement and “set the bar higher for those with whom you work.”
— “On the other end of the spectrum, if it’s a request to obfuscate or put off something you should be doing today for students, that will not be as well received,” she said. “We have to continue to raise the bar and have expectations that are continually setting our sights on what the next level of achievement might be.”
— One of DeVos’ top deputies, Frank Brogan, who leads the Office of Elementary and Secondary Education, will talk about ESSA implementation today at The National Association of State Boards of Education’s legislative conference.
— Meanwhile, CCSSO will hear from an all-star lineup of lawmakers today. Senate HELP Chairman Lamar Alexander (R-Tenn.) will tell the group that he and House education leader Bobby Scott (D-Va.) “share an interest” in ensuring states are “holding schools accountable” and fully complying with ESSA, according to a preview of his remarks. “This is an important year because we will start to really see the fruit of the work you all are doing,” he plans to say.
HIGHER EDUCATION HUFFMAN APOLOGIZES: The actress said in a statement she's “ashamed” after authorities revealed she agreed to pay at least $15,000 to arrange college entrance exam cheating for her oldest daughter. The charges of conspiracy to commit mail fraud and honest services mail fraud, to which Huffman will plead guilty, carry a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison, three years of supervised release and a fine of at least $250,000.
— "I am ashamed of the pain I have caused my daughter , my family, my friends, my colleagues and the educational community," she said Monday. "I want to apologize to them and, especially, I want to apologize to the students who work hard every day to get into college, and to their parents who make tremendous sacrifices to support their children and do so honestly."
— The scheme involved bribing coaches and college administrators — with about $25 million in payments over seven years — and paying off college entrance exam administrators to allow students to cheat on their tests. A dozen other parents will also plead guilty, as will the former head coach of men's tennis at the University of Texas at Austin, who personally accepted $60,000 in cash and another $40,000 directed to the UT tennis program in bribes to designate an applicant as a recruited athlete. Benjamin Wermund has more .
STATE NEWS STATE HIGHER ED FUNDING SLOW TO RECOVER: A decade after the start of the Great Recession, state funding for higher education has only recovered halfway, according to a report out today by the State Higher Education Executive Officers Association. At the same time, a growing reliance on tuition remains at a near high, the study said.
— Funding fell more than $2,000 per student during the recession — and was still about $1,000 below pre-recession levels by 2018 , per the report, which said appropriations for higher education averaged $7,853 per student last year.
— Despite that, state financial aid for students at public institutions has increased for four straight years and 2018 saw an 8.7 percent increase in state aid — the largest since the Great Recession. State aid per full-time students reached an all-time high of $752, nearly 10 percent of all appropriations, according to the report.
— Tuition revenue, meanwhile, was flat in 2018 , the first time since the Great Recession that net tuition revenue did not significantly exceed inflation rates. Tuition revenue has risen in all but two of the last 25 years. Among the possible reasons for the stagnation, according to the report: Declining international student enrollment.
School Safety PRINCIPALS CONNECT TO HELP PEERS IN SCHOOL SHOOTING AFTERMATH: The National Association of Secondary School Principals formed a new network consisting of principals who have experienced a shooting at their school. The goal is for participants to be a comfort and resource to other principals who experience a similar incident. The involved principals seek to “share their aggregated knowledge immediately with colleagues in crisis” and advocate for the “needs of schools both to prevent shootings and help schools recover from them,” NASSP said in a press release.
— NASSP said an initial group of principals from 87 different school shootings since 2013 that form the network met earlier this month in Reston, Va., at NASSP’s headquarters. The network includes Ty Thompson, principal at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., where 17 died last year, and Jake Heibel, principal of Great Mills High School in Great Mills, Md., where one student was fatally shot last year.
K-12 GROUPS SPOTLIGHT SCHOOL INTEGRATION: The National Coalition on School Diversity and The Century Foundation will hold a briefing today on how all levels of government can support school integration. Speakers include American Federation of Teachers President Randi Weingarten.
— The Century Foundation, a progressive think tank, is calling for a host of school integration policies in a new report that argues the federal government has failed to adequately support school diversity in recent decades, directly contributing to rising racial and income segregation in public schools.
— Among the policies the report promotes are the Strength in Diversity Act — legislation that would provide $120 million in competitive grants to districts to reduce segregation — and a boost in Title 1 funding levels for voluntary school integration efforts. The report also calls for enacting a federal pre-clearance requirement to review efforts by “wealthier and whiter districts” to secede from integrated school districts and ending the prohibition on using federal funds to transport students for integration.
REPORT ROLL CALL — Chiefs for Change, a bipartisan network of state and district education leaders, has a a new report that provides a detailed, state-by-state analysis of inequities in education leadership and outlines solutions to help more women, and women of color in particular, become district superintendents and state chiefs.
— The State of American Higher Education Outcomes in 2019 , released by the center-left think tank Third Way, examines critical measures of student success at four-year, two-year, and certificate-granting institutions and finds room for improvement in terms of completion rates, student earnings and loan repayment.
— A new series of “Districts at Work” case studies from nonprofit Education Resource Strategies finds that an often missing critical element in school reform is whether the central office effectively supports schools by setting the right strategic priorities to support their vision and following through with tough resource trade-offs and redesigned processes.
— City threatens to close yeshivas over measles threat: POLITICO PRO New York.
— Bye-Bye Bergen: Brooklyn school sheds slave-owner family name: The City.
— Kansas conservatives fail again in quest for big changes to school funding, oversight: The Wichita Eagle.
— Here’s your first chance to tell New York senators how you feel about the city’s segregated specialized high schools: Chalkbeat.
Because my first grader has been rehearsing this song for a school performance Friday (and now it’s stuck in my head). Follow the Pro Education team: @khefling ( khefling@politico.com ), @mstratford @BenjaminEW ( bwermund@politico.com ), @ngaudiano @JaneNorman ( jnorman@politico.com ).

title: Mexico on track to pass labor reform required in USMCA
content:
With help from Adam Behsudi, Doug Palmer and Megan Cassella
QUICK FIX Mexico is poised to pass major labor reform this month, removing one of the roadblocks that House Democrats have said is an obstacle to congressional consideration of the new North American trade pact.
— Mexican tomato growers offered the Commerce Department a proposal for a new agreement with the U.S. that would raise the price floor for selling tomatoes in the United States.
— Canada is preparing to refresh its list of U.S. products facing retaliatory tariffs as it continues to press for the U.S. to drop its steel and aluminum tariffs.
IT'S TUESDAY, APRIL 9! recommends everyone listen to the Peterson Institute for International Economics’ Trade Talks podcast this week to hear more about Mexico’s history of trade. Know of any podcasts I should be listening to? Have trade news to share? Let me know: srodriguez@politico.com or @sabrod123 .
Driving the Day MEXICO ON TRACK TO PASS LABOR LAW REQUIRED IN USMCA: Mexico is expected to pass a major labor reform law later this month that would check off one of its commitments under the replacement deal for NAFTA.
The labor changes would partially remove one of the roadblocks House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has said is stopping Congress from considering the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement. The labor law would completely overhaul the country’s existing union structure, which has long been criticized for failing to protect workers.
Celeste Drake, trade policy specialist for the AFL-CIO, said Mexico’s latest draft bill “is an improvement and meets a key criteria of ensuring workers can vote on their collective bargaining agreements.”
AMLO’s plan: Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador and his administration have repeatedly said Mexico would deliver on its promise to overhaul workers’ rights regulations, as it is a domestic policy priority for the left-leaning populist.
“There’s a coincidence of opinion with López Obrador and the Democrats in U.S. on this — in the sense of wanting to strengthen the protection of workers’ rights,” Kenneth Smith Ramos, chief NAFTA negotiator under former Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, told POLITICO.
Not so fast: Speaker Nancy Pelosi has said lawmakers will need to see how Mexico implements the new labor law before they consider USMCA.
Sen. Sherrod Brown , another Democrat closely following the deal, agrees with Pelosi “that both enactment and implementation of labor law reforms that comply with the standards outlined in the agreement are necessary before Congress should consider the new NAFTA,” one of his staffers told POLITICO.
Your host has more here .
MEXICAN TOMATO INDUSTRY LOOKS FOR COMPROMISE: The Mexican tomato industry has offered a proposal that would significantly raise the price floor on its tomatoes sold in the U.S., an attorney representing the growers said Monday. The push for a new deal comes as Mexican growers look to avoid restarting an anti-dumping probe that could result in steep duties on their tomatoes.
"What we're hoping is the new proposal, which we've put to the Commerce Department, is received well by them and by Florida. We think it's extremely strong,” said Bob LaRussa, an attorney with Shearman and Sterling, who is representing the Mexican growers.
If both sides reach a deal, it would replace a six-year-old “suspension” agreement that Commerce would withdraw from on May 7. But Mexican growers are prepared to fight the issue before the International Trade Commission if Commerce is not willing to agree to a fair deal, LaRussa said.
Florida growers react: Florida Tomato Exchange welcomed the Mexican proposal, saying it “contains some useful suggestions on how to prevent circumvention of the suspension agreement by Mexican producers.”
Doug Palmer has the latest here .
COMPANY SEEKS 30 PERCENT TITANIUM SPONGE PRICE INCREASE: The company behind the Commerce Department’s latest Section 232 import investigation wants the Trump administration to negotiate a “collaborative” agreement with Japan to raise the price of titanium sponge by roughly 30 percent. Titanium Metals Corp., also known as TIMET, filed its petition with Commerce last year but only made it public on Monday afternoon. Titanium sponge is used to make titanium used in a number of high-tech and military applications.
“TIMET believes America’s titanium sponge industry can be put on sound economic footing again by restoring prices for titanium sponge to 2013 levels, which were about 30% above current levels,” the company said in its brief. “Those price levels allowed TIMET and [Allegheny Technologies Inc.], as well as Japanese producers, to operate their titanium sponge plants at a sustainable cost that encouraged reinvestment in the titanium sponge industry. A combination of bilateral agreements, tariffs and quotas can achieve sustainable economics.”
CANADA TO REFRESH PRODUCTS FACING RETALIATION OVER U.S. STEEL TARIFFS: Canadian officials will soon change the list of U.S. products facing tariffs in retaliation for U.S. duties on steel and aluminum, Canadian Ambassador to the U.S. David MacNaughton said Monday.
Coming soon: MacNaughton said the retaliation list will be refreshed “shortly” and will likely be released within the next week. He added there “are no negotiations at the present moment” to resolve the dispute over the Section 232 tariffs.
It’s the latest sign that the Trump administration is not close to lifting its tariffs on steel and aluminum from Mexico and Canada. A number of lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have told President Donald Trump that lifting the tariffs is necessary to get USMCA through Congress.
Refresher: Canada imposed retaliatory tariffs on nearly $12.5 billion worth of U.S. goods in July in response to Trump’s tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum in the name of national security. Mexico has also discussed changing the items on its retaliation list, but officials have not announced a date to update those countermeasures, which hit roughly $3 billion worth of U.S. goods. More here .
GRASSLEY BEATS HIS 232 DRUM: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee took to the floor on Monday afternoon to publicly urge Trump to lift the steel and aluminum tariffs against Canada and Mexico to clear the way for the USMCA.
Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) called for a resolution that “would acknowledge that we need our allies to help us deal with the source of the overcapacity problems. And that source of the problem is China.”
Doing so would allow Congress to “forge ahead” with the USMCA, Grassley said, adding the deal needs to be approved this year.
WHITE HOUSE OFFICIAL POSITIVE ABOUT PROSPECTS FOR EU TALKS: The U.S. and European Union will see “momentum” in potential trade talks in the coming year, outgoing White House trade adviser Clete Willems said Monday at the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. “I absolutely think something very positive can be accomplished this year,” he said.
Even though Brussels and Washington are hung up on the inclusion of agriculture in the talks and the U.S. continues to dangle the threat of auto tariffs, Willems said the two sides have maintained a constructive agenda when it comes to future EU purchases of natural gas and soybeans. Confronting China and addressing WTO reform are also constructive areas, he said.
Still, the senior official recognized political headwinds, including upcoming European Parliament elections. He also noted that some EU member states may pose more of a problem in getting the effort off the ground. “France in particular hasn’t been super helpful linking unrelated issues into the FTA,” Willems said.
FRENCH ENVOY’S FAREWELL: U.S. AND EU ARE BETTER TOGETHER: Outgoing French Ambassador Gérard Araud urged the United States and European Union to work together to confront a number of transnational challenges, including the threat posed by China.
“It’s really my last word: Let’s invent together a new transatlantic agenda to defend our liberal democracies,” Araud said last week at a farewell party. “Internet, artificial intelligence, trade, climate change, biodiversity, tax evasion, respect for privacy should be handled by Americans and Europeans acting together because they share the same values. If we don’t do it, China will impose its authoritarian model.”
Araud, who is retiring from France’s diplomatic service, will be moving to New York, where he lived from 2009 to 2014 when he was France’s ambassador to the United Nations. “In Washington, there are too many squirrels and trees,” he said.
AUTO COMPANIES ON TARIFF PROTECTION: NO THANKS: Representatives of Ford and Fiat Chrysler provided a gentle reminder that the U.S. auto industry is not a supporter of nor do they need Trump’s threatened tariffs on cars and parts. They also expressed hope that the threat is just a negotiating strategy.
“I don’t think this administration’s end goal is tariffs. Their end goal is new trade agreements,” Shane Karr, head of external affairs for Fiat Chrysler, said at the Chamber event Monday. “The question of whether we have to suffer tariffs is a question of whether or not we can get through the negotiation process and into a free trade agreement.”
“I think the administration’s looking for leverage with an objective, I think, to reduce tariffs globally rather than to increase them,” said Michael Sheridan, vice president of international government relations at Ford.
DON’T MISS MORNING MONEY AT #MIGLOBAL NEXT WEEK: Just one week left to sign up for the special edition Morning Money newsletter from the Milken Institute Global Conference. POLITICO’s Ben White will detail the top conversations, major takeaways, and buzzy VIP sightings straight from one of the most influential yearly gatherings of the world’s leading minds in business, technology, government, media, philanthropy, health care, and entertainment. Sign up today .
 USTR hikes pressure on EU and Airbus with $11B retaliation list, POLITICO Pro reports .
— China pledges to remove “unreasonable barriers and restrictions” to help SMEs amid trade war, South China Morning Post reports .
— Congress urged to expand bill to exempt Trump tariffs, POLITICO Pro reports .
— Trump’s border slowdown is a job-killer, critics say, POLITICO Pro reports . The auto industry is feeling the pain of those “very serious” delays at the border, Reuters reports .
— Trump administration exploring “range of options” to confront France on digital services tax, POLITICO Pro reports .

title: Plan to raise defense spending caps faces long odds
content:
With Wesley Morgan House Democrats may not have the progressive votes they need to approve a two-year proposal that would raise spending caps.
— The Pentagon didn’t want President Donald Trump to label the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps a terrorist organization. But he did it anyway, in what has become a familiar pattern.
— Senior officers from the five military branches head to Capitol Hill to testify on the budget today.
HAPPY TUESDAY , where we're dbrown@politico.com @dave_brown24
Budget CAPS PLAN INCHES FORWARD: Democrats hoping to push forward a budget proposal that would raise defense spending caps to $733 billion in fiscal 2020 brought up two amendments Monday night meant to win over progressive lawmakers, POLITICO’s Caitlin Emma reports .
Next step: House Budget Chairman John Yarmuth (D-Ky.) said the House may vote on the legislation Wednesday morning. He has said he can afford to lose only 17 progressive votes.
Yet as of Monday night , the odds of passage weren’t great, POLITICO’s Sarah Ferris and Heather Caygle write .
“House Democratic leaders are whipping the budget caps bill, but as of Monday night the measure still didn’t have enough votes to pass. To complicate matters, progressives aren’t unified — privately some say the fight isn’t worth it while others told POLITICO they’ll oppose the bill on the floor unless their [non-defense] spending increase is included.”
IRAN IRGC’S NEW LABEL: “The Trump administration announced Monday that it is designating a key Iranian military force as a terrorist organization, an unprecedented move against a foreign government entity that met resistance from many in the Pentagon and other departments,” write POLITICO’s Nahal Toosi, Katie Galioto and Wesley Morgan.
“The designation targets Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, a group that already faces numerous U.S. sanctions. Iranian officials have blasted the latest move, warning of ‘consequences’ for U.S. troops in the Middle East.”
Risk to troops: The Pentagon had pushed back against the designation, saying it could cause harm to U.S. troops in the region. But others note that DoD has used the excuse before, including last month when Harakat al-Nujaba was labeled a terror group. Nothing happened, giving the White House ammunition against the Pentagon’s complaint.
The move marked yet another example of Trump overruling the military , Morgan and Toosi report . Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen. Joe Dunford, along with top Pentagon officials John Rood and Kathryn Wheelbarger, resisted the move. Pat Shanahan, however, declined to put up a fight, sources say.
Iran responded by naming U.S. Central Command a terrorist organization, per The Wall Street Journal.
HOMELAND SECURITY ANOTHER DAY, ANOTHER OUSTER: “U.S. Secret Service Director Randolph Alles is leaving the administration, the White House said Monday, amounting to President Donald Trump's second shakeup at the Department of Homeland Security in as many days,” POLITICO’s Caitlin Oprysko writes . His departure comes less than a day after Kirstjen Nielsen resigned as Homeland Security secretary.
So who’s next? At least two more people face the axe, The New York Times reports . They are L. Frances Cissna, head of Citizenship and Immigration Services, and John Mitnick, DHS general counsel.
Trump’s purge of high-level DHS officials is setting off alarm bells among GOP lawmakers, write POLITICO’s Burgess Everett, John Bresnahan and Melanie Zanona.
“The president's frantic four days of bloodletting at DHS and other agencies blindsided senior Republicans, who are already fretting about difficult confirmation battles ahead. Some are worried about the rising influence of top White House aide Stephen Miller.”
FORMER SOUTHCOM CHIEFS SPEAK OUT: Five former chiefs of U.S. Southern Command have signed a statement calling for a reversal of planned foreign aid cuts to three Central American countries. Read the statement here .
HAPPENING TODAY EGYPTIAN VISIT: Trump welcomes Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi to the White House today, starting with a meeting at noon and a working lunch that wraps up around 1:30.
On Monday, 17 senators signed a letter sent to Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, urging him to address political and human rights issues in Egypt, Galioto reports .
ON THE HILL TALKING BUDGET: Leaders from the five military branches, along with special operations officials and DoD’s comptroller, all head to Capitol Hill today to testify on the fiscal 2020 budget submission.
— 9:30 a.m.: Top Navy and Marine leaders

title: Welcome to a busy day on Capitol Hill
content:
With help from Alex Guillén and Annie Snider
QUICK FIX Story Continued Below
— It's a jam-packed day on Capitol Hill, with EPA chief Andrew Wheeler testifying, House lawmakers marking up a bill related to the Paris climate accord and Democrats holding three hearings focused on climate change.
— David Bernhardt's nomination for Interior secretary is on track for a final vote this week after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell filed cloture Monday.
— EPA is working on policy "expectations" on how the agency oversees federal permitting at the state level, an agency official signaled this week, ahead of the president's expected executive order focused on the topic.
GOOD MORNING, IT'S TUESDAY! Cheniere's Khary Cauthen notched another trivia win for correctly identifying Felix Frankfurter as the most recent Supreme Court justice born abroad, in Austria. For today: Who was the only president who studied to be a doctor? THREE'S COMPANY: House lawmakers are leaving town midweek while Democrats hold their annual retreat, but not before holding three hearings today on climate change.
Former Secretary of State John Kerry and former Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel will testify to a House Oversight Committee hearing on the national security risks of climate change.
Expect Chairman Elijah Cummings to call for united action , despite the president's criticism of climate change science. "Unfortunately, instead of mobilizing efforts to fight climate change, President Trump has attacked the science, weakened environmental protections, and undermined U.S. leadership abroad," he'll say, according to an excerpt from his opening statement. "I understand that there may be differences of opinion on how we should respond, but there should be no uncertainty about whether we should respond."
— Recall: Kerry and Hagel joined senior national security experts in a March letter to warn President Donald Trump against forming an advisory panel to challenge the scientific consensus on climate change.
Later today, Oversight’s Environment Subcommittee holds a hearing on inaction in addressing climate change. The panel will feature former Sen. Tim Wirth, Columbia University economist Jeffrey Sachs and Princeton University geoscience professor Michael Oppenheimer, a participant in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. The afternoon hearing will explore "the scientific consensus on climate change established in the 1980s, the role of the fossil fuel industry in spreading misinformation, and the consequences of policy inaction."
At the same time this afternoon, the House Homeland Security Emergency Preparedness, Response and Recovery Subcommittee will hold its own hearing on climate change and the "homeland security impacts." The hearings follow a recent Pentagon report that found flooding, drought and wildfires driven by climate change pose threats to two-thirds of U.S. military installations.
DON’T MISS MORNING MONEY AT #MIGLOBAL NEXT WEEK: Just one week left to sign up for the special edition Morning Money newsletter from the Milken Institute Global Conference. POLITICO’s Ben White will detail the top conversations, major takeaways, and buzzy VIP sightings straight from one of the most influential yearly gatherings of the world’s leading minds in business, technology, government, media, philanthropy, health care, and entertainment. Sign up today .
DATAPOINT Antarctica has lost 4.76 trillion tons of ice over a four-decade period fueled by the intrusion of warm, salty circumpolar deep water, according to a recent study in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. POLITICO Pro DataPoint's Patterson Clark reports on the changes in ice mass for the continent from 1979 to 2017 here .
View the full DataPoint graphic here . Want to add DataPoint to your Pro account? Learn more .
ALSO ON THE HILL THAT WAS QUICK: The Colorado River drought contingency plan that would help the waterway as it faces a long-running drought cleared both chambers of Congress on Monday with bipartisan support. The bill, H.R. 2030 (116) — which was introduced last week — passed by a voice vote in the House with identical legislation, S. 1057 , clearing the Senate a few minutes later, Pro's Annie Snider reports . The bill now heads to the president's desk.
WHEELER IN THE HOUSE: Wheeler is on the Hill again today to talk about the president's requested cuts to his agency's budget for fiscal 2020. The EPA chief will testify before the House Energy and Commerce Environment and Climate Change Subcommittee, following Trump's call for a 31 percent cut to EPA's budget over current enacted funding levels. If you go: The hearing begins at 10 a.m. in 2123 Rayburn.
ALSO TODAY: The House Foreign Affairs Committee will take its turn marking up Democratic leadership's climate bill, H.R. 9 (116) , to bar the president from exiting the Paris climate agreement.
The bill is on the fast track: The House E&C Committee advanced the measure last week, amid criticism from committee Republicans that Democrats were not following regular order since they did not convene a hearing with administration witnesses for feedback nor held a subcommittee markup.
BERNHARDT VOTE COMING SOON: The Senate will vote by the end of this week to confirm David Bernhardt's nomination to lead the Interior Department permanently after Majority Leader Mitch McConnell filed for cloture on the nomination Monday, Pro's Ben Lefebvre reports .
Keep in mind: Senators are expected to head home for a two-week recess at the end of this week, and Republicans have signaled they want to move quickly on Bernhardt's nomination. Democrats may have lost a bit of the wind in their sails after Democratic Sen. Martin Heinrich 's surprise flip in support of Bernhardt in committee — but Sen. Ron Wyden is still pushing for an investigation into Bernhardt's lobbyist past.
AROUND THE AGENCIES EPA WORKING ON PERMITTING 'EXPECTATIONS' POLICY FOR STATES: EPA will write a "national set of expectations" policy governing how the agency oversees the "quality and timeliness" of federal permitting being done by the states, according to acting Deputy Administrator Henry Darwin. "It would allow us to create a basis by which we could start having meaningful conversations about the health of individual permits and also permitting programs that can then serve as the basis for talking about differential oversight," he told state officials at a gathering of the Environmental Council of the States.
"We don't have any preconceived notions about what this actually will look like in detail," Darwin added. "It shouldn't be viewed as us testing the states or grading the states."
Maia Bellon, director of Washington State's Department of Ecology, warned Darwin against "Monday morning quarterbacking." Different states deal with different standards and many are already working hard, she added. "If it's gap-filling or support that we need in certain areas, I'm all for that. But I would like to just recommend to you that … many of us have an incredible background and robust permitting programs so it may be an exhaustive effort for you to get into the weeds on all the permits of one state, let alone all 50 of us," Bellon said.
Reading between the lines: Timeliness in deciding on permits has been a major goal of the Trump EPA; Darwin earlier had noted that former Administrator Scott Pruitt had set a goal of deciding on all permits within six months. Pending applications older than six months were down 40 percent over the last 10 months, according to Darwin. Asked if EPA would develop a six-month goal for the states, a spokesman said: "We will be working with the states to establish appropriate timeframes."
And don't forget: The Trump administration has also been working on an executive order relating to pipelines that is expected to target, among other things, states' authority under section 401 of the Clean Water Act to certify — or decertify — projects relating to water quality implications. The use of that authority by states like Washington, and the length of time they take in reviewing those applications is expected to be a top target in the long-discussed EO.
NO, THANKS: Energy Secretary Rick Perry weighed in on rumors he's being considered to replace Kirstjen Nielsen as Homeland Security secretary, telling Bloomberg : "I'm happy where I am and the president is happy where I am."
MAILBAG GREENS OPPOSE OKLAHOMA JUDGE NOMINEE: The League of Conservation Voters sent a letter to senators Monday calling on them to oppose the nomination of Patrick Wyrick for U.S. district judge for the Western District of Oklahoma.
"As Solicitor General of Oklahoma, Wyrick was former Oklahoma Attorney General and EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt's 'dear friend and trusted counselor,' working together on multiple cases challenging the EPA's ability to protect public lands and clean air and address climate change," LCV President Gene Karpinski writes .
MOVERS AND SHAKERS — Rachel Kyte has been added as the new dean of Tufts' Fletcher School, starting in October. Kyte is a special representative of the U.N. secretary-general and CEO of Sustainability for All. She is also the former vice president of sustainable development at the World Bank.
The Grid — "Investors should worry if climate goals are missed, report warns," Bloomberg .
— "Shell launches $300M forest plan to offset carbon emissions," Financial Times .
— "Midwest floods hammer U.S. ethanol industry, push some gasoline prices toward five-year high," Reuters .
— "Fire at Capitol Power Plant prompts 2-hour evacuation," Roll Call .
— "Pennsylvania governor under scrutiny for role in approving pipeline," The Guardian

title: Facebook and Google talk hate crimes
content:
With help from John Hendel, Cristiano Lima, Margaret Harding McGill and Jordyn Hermani. Tech giants on the Hill: Facebook and Google will testify today at a House hearing on hate crimes, the rise of white supremacy and how social media has a hand in both.
— Net neutrality latest: House lawmakers plan to take up their “Save the Internet Act,” an effort to restore the FCC’s repealed net neutrality rules, later today.
— Intergalactic regulation: The FCC and Commerce Department clash over a commission proposal for orbital debris.
GREETINGS AND WELCOME TO MORNING TECH. I’m your new host, Alexandra Levine, picking up the baton from Cristiano Lima, who left big shoes to fill. I’m as new to D.C. as I am to Politico — I moved from New York City three weeks ago to the day — and I’m not afraid to admit that I … already like it here better. (Scooters and cherry blossoms and a functional Metro, oh my!) . And
 us the details at ALL EYES ON HOUSE HATE CRIMES HEARING — Facebook and Google are back in the Hill hot seat to testify at a House Judiciary Committee hearing on hate crimes and the rise of white nationalism. That’s two weeks after Facebook banned white nationalist and white separatist content and just over three weeks since the Christchurch mosque attack was livestreamed on the platform, leaving Facebook, Twitter and YouTube scrambling to react and, more broadly, struggling to address the spread of violent content across social media. Couple that with criticism over censorship and demands for free speech, and no one seems to have answers. “I’m going to mention online hate but I’m not going to mention what could be done, because I don’t know,” president of the Zionist Organization of America, Mort Klein, who is testifying, told MT. “We know it’s terrible, but we don’t know how to stop it.”
— Representatives of several prominent advocacy groups , including the Anti-Defamation League and the National Lawyers’ Committee for Civil Rights Under Law, are among the witnesses slated to testify . Officials plan to highlight how social media has fueled the spread of white supremacist hate and demand that tech platforms be held accountable for letting hate speech proliferate unchecked. “A recent ADL survey found an overwhelming and bipartisan majority of Americans (over 80 percent) want policymakers to strengthen laws and improve law enforcement training and resources for managing online hate,” the group’s senior vice president of policy, Eileen Hershenov, said in an opening statement shared with MT. “Now is the time.”
SPEAKING OF HEARINGS… — Google will send Max Pappas, manager of external outreach and public policy partnerships, to testify at Wednesday’s Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on the Constitution hearing on tech “censorship,” according to a source familiar with the plans. Pappas joins Facebook public policy director Neil Potts on the witness list for the session, which is expected to focus on allegations that online platforms suppress conservative viewpoints. Twitter is reportedly also planning to send a representative.
NET NEUTRALITY HITS THE FLOOR — House lawmakers today will begin floor debate on Democrats’ Save the Internet Act, H.R. 1644 (116) , aimed at restoring the FCC’s repealed net neutrality rules, as well as 12 amendments. Rep. Tom Cole (R-Okla.) previewed GOP objections during a Rules Committee session Monday evening, calling the measure a “Democratic takeover of the internet.” Cole lamented Democrats’ rejection of GOP requests to negotiate compromise legislation that would avoid utility-style regulations, adding, “Common ground exists.” Rep. Mike Doyle (D-Pa.) countered that Democrats sought to address GOP concerns by adding to the bill clarifying language to codify limits to FCC authority.
— Amendments on deck: Only two Republican amendments will receive votes: one from Bob Latta (R-Ohio) to force the FCC to share which regulations the bill would permanently exempt broadband from and one from Michael Burgess (R-Texas) compelling a GAO study on “the influence of all entities” in the “internet ecosystem.”
— Doyle expressed confidence in passage. “209 co-sponsors,” he remarked to reporters Monday night. But will any Republicans join? Rep. Jeff Fortenberry (R-Neb.), who last year co-sponsored a strong net neutrality bill with former Rep. Mike Coffman (R-Colo.), said he’s not planning to revive that bill and criticized the terms of the current debate, which he said is too focused on broadband providers and not tech giants that prioritize content. “I just think the whole construct is hypocritical,” Fortenberry told reporters Monday.
COMMERCE VS. FCC ON SPACE DEBRIS — The Commerce Department in comments made public Monday warned the FCC to stand down on its review of regulations governing orbital debris — that is, decommissioned satellites and other manmade junk that presents a collision risk to anything else placed in orbit. Commerce noted that President Donald Trump has charged it and other executive branch agencies to encourage U.S. commercial space innovations through a series of Space Policy Directives.
— The department asked the FCC to defer action on its proceeding , launched in November, until the Space Policy Directives are carried out.
MUELLER REPORT BUZZ — Any day now, folks. We’ve just about hit mid-April, so Attorney General William Barr could release the redacted version of Robert Mueller’s report at any time. MT, for one, is eager to map out how technology and the internet played a role — from phishing attacks targeting Democratic operatives to fishy online personas.
— In the interim, take note of a related hearing today at 9 a.m. in federal district court: EPIC v. Department of Justice . The Electronic Privacy Information Center, a privacy watchdog, filed the lawsuit after the DOJ failed to respond to the group’s recent Freedom of Information Act request for the Mueller documents on Russian election interference.
AND FINALLY — The FTC series “ Competition and Consumer Privacy in the 21st Century ” resumes today with more than 30 policy experts convening to talk privacy and data risks at a time when the troubles facing tech giants (and the dangers posed by tech giants) are growing bigger by the day. Here’s the list of speakers for day one, including FTC Chairman Joe Simons and FTC Commissioner Noah Phillips.
— Alastair Mactaggart, who led the fight for California’s landmark consumer privacy law, will also be among the panelists. His goal today is to highlight the so-called “privacy paradox.” “The narrative that tech companies want to continue to try to push is that consumers don’t care about this because even when we give them options, they opt out,” Mactaggart told MT. “But they have some of the smartest people in the world making it as hard as possible to control your privacy. There is a tremendous consumer thirst for this, if it were easy.”
Transitions — Jared Sher, former executive vice president and deputy general counsel at 21st Century Fox, joins the Internet & Television Association as chief counsel of program network policy and deputy general counsel. … Alison Nemeth Steger , a former legal adviser to FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, moves to Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP in Washington as an associate in the communications and media group.
Silicon Valley Must Reads — California to Canada: The Canadian government is considering regulating Facebook and other social platforms, BuzzFeed News reports .
— If you can’t tweet something nice...: An SEC commissioner says holding Elon Musk in contempt of court for his use of Twitter is "reasonable," Reuters reports .
Quick Downloads — Ad hoc: U.S. advertising groups “have banded together to lobby Congress to ensure federal online privacy legislation is less strict than a law scheduled to go into effect in California in 2020,” Reuters reports .
— Ctrl+Alt+Undo: "Wikipedia isn't officially a social network. But the harassment can get ugly," The New York Times reports .
— ICYMI: The New Zealand privacy commissioner said very publicly that Facebook is run by “morally bankrupt pathological liars,” The Verge reported

title: Democrats to push DOJ on Obamacare stance
content:
With help from Sarah Owermohle, Adam Cancryn, Renuka Rayasam and Mohana Ravindranath
QUICK FIX Story Continued Below
— Democrats will push the Trump administration to explain its new stance on the Obamacare court battle , as House committee leaders demand transparency and Attorney General Bill Barr goes to the Hill.
— Pharmacy benefit managers are in the spotlight , as the Senate Finance Committee will grill executives on PBMs' role in high drug prices.
— House Democrats are launching the Black Maternal Health Caucus, citing the high death rate from preventable, pregnancy-related complications.
IT'S TUESDAY PULSE — And the men's college basketball championship is in the books, with the University of Virginia edging Texas Tech. (Your author is glad that Virginia graduates — who include NIH Director Francis Collins, several Kennedys and a few POLITICO executives — finally caught a break.)
Speaking of sports: Rachel Roubein ( rroubein@politico.com ) is on deck to be tonight's pinch-hitter for PULSE. Your regular author will return Thursday; tips to ddiamond@politico.com .
Driving the Day TODAY: DEMOCRATS WANT ANSWERS FROM DOJ ON OBAMACARE — Expect a multi-pronged assault as lawmakers push the Trump administration in a press conference and a separate hearing on the DOJ budget.
The Justice Department two weeks ago called for the courts to strike down the entire ACA, a shift in position.
— At 9 a.m.: House Committee leaders to demand transparency on ACA lawsuit. Energy and Commerce Chair Frank Pallone and Judiciary Chair Jerry Nadler will be among the Democrats unveiling letters to the administration, requesting documents that explain why the Justice Department changed its position. Livestream .
The effort's also backed by Oversight Chair Elijah Cummings, Ways and Means Chair Richard Neal and Education and Labor Chair Bobby Scott.
— At 9:30 a.m.: BILL BARR faces a House Appropriations subcommittee over his agency's budget request . It's the first time the attorney general will testify since DOJ changed its position on Obamacare, and while Mueller report-related questions will dominate, Democrats are planning on pushing on health care too. See hearing
Barr will be back again tomorrow to face Senate appropriators.
— Meanwhile: DOJ wants July oral arguments in the Texas case. The department on Monday filed a motion to expedite oral arguments in the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals. It indicated that its proposed timeline is unopposed by the other parties in the case.
ALSO TODAY: PHARMACY BENEFIT MANAGERS FACE THE SPOTLIGHT — Executives from Cigna's Express Scripts, UnitedHealth's OptumRx, CVS Health's Caremark, Humana and Prime Therapeutics are in front of the Senate Finance Committee this morning.
— What's on tap: Chair Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa) and ranking member Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) are expected to push for more transparency on how the business model works and whether drug rebates are actually benefiting patients.
"They're kind of a secret organization," Grassley told NPR. "I ask people to explain what they're doing and nobody seems to give you the same answer twice." Watch 10:15 a.m. hearing .
— How PBMs will likely respond: They've already telegraphed plans to engage in a time-honored tradition — point the finger at other health industry players, in this case drug makers.
… Ahead of today's hearing, Wyden warned pharma companies that their pricing practices remain under scrutiny.
"In order to prevent a cash grab that gives drug makers a windfall and leaves consumers stuck with high prices, Congress must take significant action to end business as usual in the broken drug pricing system," Wyden said in a statement Monday night. More for Pros .
DON’T
IN CONGRESS House Democrats launch Black Maternal Health Caucus. Reps. Alma Adams and Lauren Underwood are forming a caucus focused on African-American women’s maternal health, amid a steep rise in the maternal mortality rate for black women, POLITICO's Adam Cancryn reports.
“Black women are nearly four times more likely than white women—and more than twice as likely as women of other races—to die from preventable, pregnancy-related complications,” Adams and Underwood wrote in a dear colleague letter outlining the need for more research and policies aimed at improving black maternal health.
The lawmakers officially launch the caucus this morning with 51 members — including top Democrats Steny Hoyer, Jim Clyburn and Katherine Clark.
JIM JORDAN, MARK MEADOWS are warning pharma not to cooperate with Oversight investigation. The two senior House Republicans are telling drug companies that Democrats may leak their information in an attempt to lower their stock prices, BuzzFeed's Paul McLeod reports .
Democrats say the allegations are misleading and that warning companies not to cooperate with an investigation breaks the norms of Congress — and is possibly unprecedented.
ROSA DeLAURO threatens lawsuit after HHS bars access to facility for migrant kids. The Connecticut Democrat — who holds HHS' purse strings, as chair of the House Appropriations Labor-HHS subcommittee — warned the agency that she’s reviewing “legal remedies” after three House Democrats were barred from accessing a Florida facility where migrant children are housed.
“This will not stand,” said DeLauro, citing a 2018 law that members of Congress must be allowed to access the facilities. “[W]e will not back down from conducting the oversight the American people sent us here to do.”
— Three Florida members — Reps. Debbie Wasserman Schultz , Donna Shalala and Debbie Mucarsel-Powell — on Monday were denied entry to the HHS-funded facility in Homestead, Florida. The members were told that they needed to schedule visits two weeks in advance, DeLauro’s office told POLITICO, which Democrats maintain would defeat the purpose of conducting oversight.
— HHS says two-weeks notice is necessary for scheduling a visit. "This has been HHS policy since 2015," said Evelyn Stauffer, an HHS senior adviser, who added that the policy is necessary to protect the privacy and well-being of the kids. "It meets our current statutory obligation to provide members of Congress with facility access."
INSIDE THE HUMPHREY BUILDING SEEMA VERMA bashes government-run health care again. The CMS administrator called proposals for “Medicare for All” and government-run health care the “greatest threat to our innovation in our country,” speaking at the World Medical Innovation Forum in Boston Monday night.
"It is the private health care system that have in place that is actually spurring that innovation" in medicine, she said. One of Verma's stated goals on Monday: to ensure that technology approved by the FDA can more rapidly get coverage under Medicare, POLITICO's Mohana Ravindranath reports.
AROUND THE NATION New York City: Health department threatens to close yeshivas over measles threat. The unprecedented move comes after five yeshivas in Williamsburg and surrounding neighborhoods flouted a directive to keep unvaccinated children away from school grounds until the measles outbreak subsided, POLITICO's Amanda Eisenberg reports. More than 40 people have contracted measles because one yeshiva ignored the mandate, according to the city health department. More for Pros .
Texas: State Senate passes abortion bill. In a preliminary measure, the state Senate passed a bill ( TX SB23 (19R) ) Monday that would fine doctors up to $100,000 and charge them with a third-degree felony for not saving an infant after an abortion attempt. One Democrat joined the 19 Republican state Senators to pass the bill and Senators will take a final vote today. A House committee passed a similar bill ( TX HB16 (19R) ) last week.
The territories face Medicaid shortfalls. In the Washington Post, CBPP's Javier Balmaceda warns that the Senate's failure to pass a funding bill is putting Medicaid programs in Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands and American Samoa at risk.
More than 8 percent of health spending is on administrative costs. That's according to a new issue brief from the left-leaning Center for American Progress, which suggests tactics like global budgeting would curb those costs.
"Simplifying the payment system should be an essential part of future health reform and would make the U.S. system work better for taxpayers and patients alike," Emily Gee and Topher Spiro write.
NAMES IN THE NEWS DAN MENDELSON joins Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe. Mendelson, the founder and former CEO of Avalere Health, will be an operating partner on the private equity firm's health care team. More .
JULIE MORITA joins Robert Wood Johnson Foundation as executive vice president. Morita, the current commissioner of the Chicago Department of Public Health, will oversee the foundation's programming, policy, research and communications. More . Morita appeared on POLITICO's "Pulse Check" podcast in 2017.
WHAT WE'RE READING By Victoria Colliver
Texas lawmakers this session tried to keep secret a series of reports on state government efficiency in health care and other policy areas that were normally released to the public. So the Texas Tribune obtained and published them. (Spoiler alert: they’re not flattering). More from the Tribune’s Edgar Walters.
Sandy Hook families want to use litigation as a weapon against the gun industry — much like how the tobacco industry’s practices were exposed by lawsuits filed against cigarette makers. More from Rick Rojas and Kristin Hussey in The New York Times.
How a small, rural Northern California town managed to reduce hospital utilization by 44 percent in less than a year, Lauran Hardin and Shelly Trumbo explain in STAT. More .
Michael Bennet’s prostate cancer diagnosis made him run for president, writes The Atlantic’s Edward-Isaac Dovere. More .

title: Mnuchin to face a brutal grilling
content:
Mnuchin preview — Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is in for a brutal grilling this afternoon before the House Financial Services Committee. MM spoke to Cap Alpha’s Ian Katz about what to expect: “[Dems] are going to be very aggressive. They haven’t really had a shot at him like this. And we’ve got the tax return issues and sanctions on Russia and the Fed nominees.
“I do think the GSEs will come up and how hard they are going to push on that. These hearings are rarely about international issues [as they are billed to be]. To be a success, Mnuchin will just have to not say anything that angers President Trump, which means he is certainly going to anger committee Democrats.” (Mnuchin testifies early in the day before House Appropriations subcommittee)
Could the GOP stand up to Trump on the Fed? — Our Victoria Guida writes here about the possibility that Senate Republicans, who generally give President Trump what he wants, could draw the line at his efforts to influence Federal Reserve policy:
“[I]nterviews with numerous influential Republicans in the Senate and House show an overwhelming faith in the Fed under Powell.”
Is the Fed in full retreat? — Tim Clark, who started the stress tests for Too Big to Fail banks at the Fed writes in a new POLITICO op-ed that the central bank is unilaterally disarming: “After nine years of pitched battle with the banks over stress tests, the Fed has decided to retreat and, in the process, weakened its capacity to hold them accountable for dangerously bad practices.” Read more .
GOOD TUESDAY MORNING — Well, that turned into quite an NCAA title game! Congrats to UVA and POLITICO's Marty Kady! ... @AubreeWeaver Victoria Guida on the Federal Reserve’s proposal that would give large banks more time to update their contingency plans for how to break themselves up in the event of bankruptcy.
HAPPENING TODAY — POLITICO PLAYBOOK authors JAKE SHERMAN and ANNA PALMER's new book "The Hill to Die On" is in stores everywhere today. They will sit down with NYT'S MAGGIE HABERMAN tonight at Community Theater in Brooklyn at 7:30 to talk about the book, and news of the day. The event . Order the book .
MM RANT SECTION — Via Wall Street veteran and Brown economics professor Larry Rand: “As for Bernie and AOC, how can you support MMT yet rail against the so-called “bailout” of the financial system in 2008-2009? What hypocrisy!”
Driving the Day President Trump meets with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi … House Financial Services subcommittee has a hearing at 10:00 a.m. on the Community Reinvestment Act … Mnuchin testifies before the full Financial Services Committee at 2:00 p.m. … NFIB small business report at 6:00 a.m. expected to tick down to 101.6 from 101.7.
EARLY BANK HEARING PREP — Tons of chatter already about Wednesday’s big bank CEO hearing. Via Compass Point’s Isaac Boltansky: “If you are looking for a nuanced consideration of the regulatory regime for the nation’s largest banks, we recommend looking elsewhere. This hearing is likely to be more politics than policy given the combination of bright lights and populist undercurrents.”
MM EXCLUSIVE FIRST LOOK — Better Markets will be out today with a report ahead of the hearing entitled: “The RAP Sheet for Wall Street’s biggest banks’ crime spree.” Per release: “The Report released today details, for the first time, that, of the more than $29 trillion in total bailouts, the six biggest banks in the country (Bank of America, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, and Wells Fargo) received more than $8.2 trillion, or nearly one-third of the total bailouts provided to the entire financial system” Full report .
The bankers will argue by contrast that they are much better capitalized and that post-crisis regulatory reforms have done nothing to make the system less safe. They will also argue that record profits does not mean more risk.
POLL BLAST: BIDEN STILL ON TOP — Our Steven Shepherd: “The spate of negative stories about Joe Biden’s interactions with women hasn’t upended the former vice president’s standing as presumptive 2020 Democratic frontrunner, according to the first national poll of the presidential field conducted since the controversy erupted .”
More on Mnuchin — Larry Summers in WaPo argues that the IRS chief has to release Trump’s tax returns and Mnuchin must not stop him.
Via CAP’s Gregg Gelzinis: “Secretary Mnuchin should be held accountable for casting aside the FSOC’s mission by deregulating the remaining nonbank SIFIs, making it more difficult to use the Council’s tools, and dismantling its institutional capabilities from within. The financial system is less resilient today as a direct result of his actions.”
MARKETS S&P 500 EKES OUT GAIN — AP’s Stan Choe: “U.S. stock indexes took a round trip Monday, erasing their early-morning losses to end the day close to where they started. The S&P 500 eked out a small gain, enough to prolong its winning streak to eight days, its longest in a year and a half. But the Dow Jones Industrial Average ended lower due to another big loss for Boeing. ” Read more .
FAANG’S RALLY HAS INVESTORS CASHING OUT — Bloomberg’s Sarah Ponczek: “After a three-month rally that’s added more than $800 billion to the value of FAANG stocks, individual investors have decided it’s time to cash out of the high-flying names..” Read more .
PINTEREST SEEKS $11.3B VALUATION — FT’s Nicole Bullock, Hannah Murphy, Richard Waters and Tim Bradshaw: “Online scrapbooking site Pinterest on Monday said it planned to raise as much as $1.3 billion from investors at a valuation of up to $11.3 billion, below the price of its most recent private share sale. The deal could prove to be an ominous sign for Wall Street’s interest in new tech listings” Read more .
A GROWTH SURPRISE COULD SHOCK MARKETS — WSJ’s Paul Davies: “Recession fears have captured the markets’ attention in recent weeks, but some investors say the bigger impact could be a surprise return to growth. In fact, slowdown risks may be fading already, as recent data pointed in a healthier direction for China and the U.S., the dominant forces in the global economy.” FED REBUTS TRUMP — CNBC’s Jeff Cox: The Federal Reserve is rebutting … Trump's assertion that tightening monetary policy is hurting the economy. In a paper published Friday, the St. Louis Fed said the central bank's move to reduce the level of bonds on its balance sheet — ‘quantitative tightening’ as it has become known — will not have any noticeable negative impact on growth.” Read more .
MORE NAFTA, MORE PROBLEMS — Bloomberg’s Josh Wingrove: “Canada is ratcheting up pressure on the U.S. to lift tariffs on steel and aluminum — threatening to hold up the new continental trade deal and change up its own retaliatory tariffs to have a bigger impact.” Read more .
GOLDMAN PUSHES DIVERSITY EFFORTS — Bloomberg’ Sridhar Natarajan: “Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is expanding the mandate of a diversity initiative it rolled out last year to include people of color as it looks to channel more money toward under-served entrepreneurs.” Read more .
SEC CHIEF RAISES CONCERNS ABOUT RISKY LENDING — WSJ’s Gabriel Rubin: “A top markets regulator said he was concerned about the growth of loans by banks to highly indebted companies, joining other policy makers who have highlighted risks that leveraged loans could pose to financial markets. Read more .
FED LOOKS TO CHANGE BANK REGS — AP’s Martin Crutsinger: “The Federal Reserve on Monday put forward two proposals to modify regulations put in place after the 2008 financial crisis that the banking industry complained were too restrictive. The proposed regulatory changes were approved on a 4-1 vote with Fed board member Lael Brainard opposing the changes. She said they ‘would weaken important safeguards’ put in place after the crisis..” Read more .
GOLDMAN WEIGHS ‘WORLD WITHOUT BUYBACKS’ — Bloomberg’s Lu Wang: “With political scrutiny of stock buybacks growing, Goldman Sachs started assessing an extreme scenario: ‘a world without buybacks.’ The picture doesn’t look pretty. That’s because corporate demand has far exceeded that from all other investors combined, according to strategists led by David Kostin. Since 2010, net buybacks averaged $420 billion annually, while buying from households, mutual funds, pension funds and foreign investors was less than $10 billion for each, Federal Reserve data compiled by Goldman showed.” Read more .
ALSO FOR YOUR RADAR Transitions — Leigh Farris will be global head of corporate communications at The Carlyle Group. She previously was a managing director at Goldman Sachs.
NEW ON THE BOOK SHELVES — Investor David L. Bahnsen’s new book “The Case for Dividend Growth – Investing in a post-crisis world” is available now on Amazon … The latest book from the Mercatus Center’s Tyler Cowen “Big Business: A Love Letter to an American Anti-Hero” is also out now on Amazon .
TRUMP TO NOMINATE NCUA CHAIR — Per release: President Donald J. Trump has designated Rodney E. Hood as the eleventh Chairman of the National Credit Union Administration Board. Read more .

title: TRUMP’S IMMIGRATION SHAKEUP FLOORS REPUBLICANS -- Dems get first chance to grill William Barr -- SWALWELL JUMPS INTO 2020 -- House Dems struggle to unite on spending
content:
DISCOURAGE THE PURGE -- Even President Donald Trump’s GOP allies are distressed that he purged top officials at DHS and other agencies (including the Secret Service) over the past several days. Not only are they concerned that the leadership void will make it more difficult to tackle the crisis at the southern border, but they also are worried that hard-liners like White House aide Stephen Miller will have more influence over Trump’s immigration agenda — which could be disastrous for some Republicans in 2020. Just look at these alarmed responses: Sen. John Kennedy (R-La.) called the ouster of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen “classless”; Sen. John Thune (R-S.D.) warned that immigration might be a winning issue for Trump, but “it may not work for everybody else”; and Sen. John Cornyn (R-Texas) called the whole situation a “mess.”
Now, Republicans are in damage control mode, with Sen. Chuck Grassley scrambling to prevent Trump from canning any more top officials. According to the Washington Post, the Iowa Republican was even planning to go on Fox News to help plead his case to the president. But while the GOP has been more comfortable speaking out against Trump, it’s unclear just how far they are willing to go to stop him. The dispatch from Burgess, Bres and your Huddle host: https://politi.co/2D66KXx .
CREATING EVEN MORE HEADACHES … multiple news outlets reported that the Trump administration is considering reviving a version of its controversial family separation policy, which was deeply unpopular among suburban and women voters in the last election. Republicans swiftly pushed back on the idea, reports The Hill, warning that it could lead to a brutal confirmation hearing to replace Nielsen. More from Alexander Bolton: http://bit.ly/2UAwRQv .
Related read: “Trump White House plots amped-up immigration crackdown,” by Ted Hesson, Anita Kumar and Nancy Cook: https://politi.co/2Io6SFs .
SETTING THE BARR -- House Democrats will have their first shot at grilling Attorney General William Barr when he testifies today before an Appropriations subcommittee on the DOJ’s budget. While the hearing is not focused on special counsel Robert Mueller’s Russia report, Democrats plan to press him for information about when the final report will land on Capitol Hill, how heavily it will be redacted and why Barr made certain decisions when crafting an initial summary of the report. Tuesday’s hearing will likely serve as a preview of the big show on May 2, when the House Judiciary Committee plans to haul Barr in to testify. The deets from Andrew and Kyle: https://politi.co/2Kmzotp .
Related : “‘I’ve been battling Nadler for years’: Feud between Trump, Democrat rooted in decades-old New York real estate project,” via WaPo’s Rachael Bade and Josh Dawsey: https://wapo.st/2P1sHM7 .
GOOD MORNING! to all Tuesday, April 9, where your host is hoping her Game of Thrones death pool picks turn out far better than her March Madness bracket did.
MONDAY’S MOST CLICKED: USA TODAY’s story on how Nancy Pelosi is leading her divided caucus was the big winner.
HAPPENING TODAY -- POLITICO PLAYBOOK authors JAKE SHERMAN and ANNA PALMER's new book "The Hill to Die On" is in stores everywhere today. (And your Huddle host is super pumped to read this book on her upcoming beach vacation.) Order the book.
STILL SHORT -- House Democrats are slated to vote Wednesday on a budget bill that will serve as the party’s opening bid to Republicans on a looming spending caps battle. But for now, they’re still short the votes, Sarah and Heather report. The big question is whether progressives will get on board after complaining for weeks that they want even more cash for domestic programs.
House Budget chief John Yarmuth will make his case to the caucus Tuesday morning, where he’ll need to win over dozens of fellow Congressional Progressive Caucus members without losing moderates. With their first year of House control, progressive leaders want to shake up budget negotiations by demanding a near-equal split between defense and domestic programs, after years of seeing the Pentagon receive the lion’s share of discretionary dollars. Much more: https://politi.co/2D6ajgp .
Related: “Culture shock may be in store for House spending panel,” from CQ Roll Call’s Jennifer Shutt: http://bit.ly/2G9pEyt .
SWALWELL THAT ENDS WELL -- Rep. Eric Swalwell has become the latest Democrat to announce a bid for president, jumping into an already crowded field and joining two other House members in the race. The 38-year-old California Democrat, who made a name for himself through his high-profile work on the House Intelligence Committee and frequent appearances on cable news, plans to focus his platform on gun control. (Though as my colleagues noted last week , his long-shot bid is more likely to boost his post-primary career than land him in the White House.) More from The San Francisco Chronicle’s Tal Kopan : http://bit.ly/2FZPbJl .
And don’t miss this great throwback pic (h/t to CNN’s Ryan Lizza) of Swalwell, Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D-Hawaii) and former Rep. Beto O’Rourke (D-Texas), who came to Congress together in 2012 and are now all running for president: http://bit.ly/2UoiWh6 .
DON’T MISS MORNING MONEY AT #MIGLOBAL NEXT WEEK: Just one week left to sign up for the special edition Morning Money newsletter from the Milken Institute Global Conference. POLITICO’s Ben White will detail the top conversations, major takeaways, and buzzy VIP sightings straight from one of the most influential yearly gatherings of the world’s leading minds in business, technology, government, media, philanthropy, health care, and entertainment. Sign up today .
WHAT PURITY PLEDGE? -- Scores of freshman Democrats vowed to not take any money from corporate PACs on the campaign trail. But some of them are still taking personal checks or attending fundraisers hosted by corporations’ lobbyists, reports Theodoric Meyer. Examples: Rep. Gil Cisneros (D-Calif.) went to a fundraiser hosted by four lobbyists who represent major corporate clients, while Rep. Cindy Axne (D-Iowa) held a fundraiser late last month at the offices of the Washington lobbying firm Cornerstone Government Affairs.
Technically, these lawmakers aren’t violating their purity pledges. But it shows how Democrats are increasingly getting around promises to swear off corporate PAC money as the issue becomes more of a litmus test on the left. (And it also reminds me of the time the Jonas Brothers wore purity rings...) Much more: https://politi.co/2UGJYj0 .
NUNES <3’s LAWSUITS -- Rep. Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) has filed yet another lawsuit. This time, the former Intelligence Committee chairman is suing the McClatchy Company for $150 million, claiming one of its reporters teamed up with a political operative to hamper Nunes' oversight of the Hillary Clinton campaign and Russian election interference, according to Fox News. Nunes sued Twitter last month for ignoring reports of abusive behavior and censoring conservative voices. The deets from Gregg Re: https://fxn.ws/2YWzV8F .
MORNING MESSAGING -- House GOP leadership plans to play a video at their closed-door conference meeting this morning highlighting the “100 Days of Dems,” which paints Democrats as radical and extreme during their first 100 days in the House majority. Leaders want to pump their members with talking points and a clear messaging strategy before they head back to their districts for the two-week recess break.
MEET THE FRESHMAN CLASS -- A mother, an officer, and a hard-liner walk into Congress: Our new video series “Red, Fresh and Blue” goes inside the most diverse freshman class of Congress in history. Today, series host Eugene Daniels profiles Lucy McBath, who took the tragedy of her son’s murder and turned it into a history-making Congressional run. Check it out: https://politi.co/2Vymr0S .
TRANSITIONS Nothing for you today.
TODAY IN CONGRESS The House gavels in at 10 a.m., with first votes expected between 2 and 3 p.m. Today’s agenda: http://bit.ly/2U80e89 . The Senate meets at 10 a.m. to resume consideration of Daniel Desmond Domenico’s nomination to be U.S. district judge for the District of Colorado. At approximately 11 a.m., senators will vote on the motion to invoke cloture.
The Senate will recess from 12:30 p.m. to 2:15 p.m. for the weekly party luncheons.
AROUND THE HILL Rep. Alma Adams (D-N.C.) and Rep. Lauren Underwood (D-Ill.) hold a news conference to announce the launch of the Black Maternal Health Caucus at 8:30 a.m. on the House Triangle.
The House Democratic Caucus will hold a closed-door meeting at 9 a.m. in HC-5.
The House GOP caucus meets behind closed doors at 9 a.m. in HVC-215
House Energy and Commerce Chairman Frank Pallone Jr. (D-N.J.), House Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.) and other House Democrats hold a news conference to unveil new letters demanding answers on the DOJ’s health care lawsuit at 9 a.m. in HVC Studio A.
House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) and GOP leaders hold a press conference 10 a.m. in HVC Studio A.
House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-Md.) holds a pen and pad briefing with reporters at 11 a.m. in H-107.
Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.) holds a news conference with the Minority Cannabis Business Association to discuss marijuana legislation at 11 a.m. on the House Triangle.
Senate Judiciary Chairman Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) holds a news conference on the “Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act" at 12 p.m. in SD-226.
Rep. Veronica Escobar (D-Texas) holds a news conference to discuss the introduction of the "Homeland Security Improvement Act” at 12 p.m. on the House Triangle.
Rep. Tom Malinowski (D-N.J.) holds a news conference to discuss the introduction of legislation "condemning white supremacist terrorism and anti-immigrant rhetoric” at 1 p.m. in HVC Studio B.
TRIVIA MONDAY’S WINNER -- Will Henderson that John Q Adams, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison could all speak Russian, Arabic and Hebrew.
TODAY’S QUESTION -- From yours truly: Batman fanatic Sen. Patrick Leahy has appeared in multiple Batman movies. Which of his Senate colleagues also scored a cameo in one of the Batman flicks? mzanona@politico.com .
GET HUDDLE emailed to your phone each morning.

title: Back on the Hill
content:
With help from Aaron Lorenzo
QUICK FIX Story Continued Below
— IRS Commissioner Chuck Rettig today makes his first appearance before Congress since his confirmation, where he’ll likely have to break his silence on House Democrats’ efforts to get President Donald Trump’s tax returns.
— Another potential issue for Rettig this week: New statistics showing high audit rates in areas with comparatively high numbers of Earned Income Tax Credit recipients.
— Some new Tax Day polling: A new survey found that just one in six believe that the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, H.R. 1 (115) , actually cut their taxes.
WELCOME TO TUESDAY, where that is quite the battle going on over go-go music in D.C.’s Shaw neighborhood.
And our last NCAA Tournament thought of the year: Has a team ever won their final three games after being down in the last 15 seconds? Would seem unlikely!
Today also marks 159 years since the creation of the oldest known recording of the human voice, made by Edouard-Leon Scott de Martinville on his invention, the phonautograph. (Not to be confused with Thomas Edison’s phonograph, which de Martinville’s creation predated by two decades.)
Got a tip you want to scream from the rooftops? Send it here.
Email: alorenzo@politico.com , teckert@politico.com and bbecker@politico.com .
You can also reach us on Twitter at @berniebecker3
Driving the Day WELCOME BACK, MR. RETTIG: Interesting timing here for the commissioner, who returns to the Hill less than a week after House Ways and Means Chairman Richard Neal (D-Mass.) put in for Trump’s returns (and as the president’s allies are digging in their heels against that request).
Rettig himself has yet to publicly comment on Neal’s official demand for the returns, which the commissioner received by hand during a separate meeting on the Hill last week. But one way or another, that silence is almost certain to end this afternoon, when Rettig appears before a House Appropriations subcommittee about the IRS budget.
Lay of the land: Trump himself escalated the returns issue on Monday, via a retweet of Rep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), as our Caitlin Oprysko reports. (Jordan, you might recall, was one of the more strident critics of the IRS over its treatment of tea party groups seeking tax-exempt status.)
And up in the president’s home base of New York, Democratic lawmakers have introduced legislation that would allow Albany to share state tax returns with congressional committees, as our Bill Mahoney reported. There’s been no sign yet that legislative leaders will take up those proposals, after essentially ignoring other bills the past couple of years dealing with Trump’s returns. (Interesting side note: The proposal was sharply criticized by Ed Cox, the state GOP chairman — who was Richard Nixon’s son-in-law.)
HOW ABOUT THE EITC? Rettig also testifies before the Senate Finance Committee on Wednesday, and here’s another issue he could hear about this week — new findings that some of the areas in the U.S. where taxpayers are most likely to get audited have high poverty rates and lots of Earned Income Tax Credit recipients.
Those statistics also got some attention on Monday, even before Rettig’s appearances. Sen. Angus King (I-Maine) wrote in a letter to Rettig and Kirsten Wielobob, the IRS’s deputy commissioner for services and enforcement, that there were a “disproportionate” number of audits in two of his state’s poorest counties — both with average median annual incomes of around $40,000. Among the questions King asks of the agency in his letter — what the IRS will do to make sure that it “audits taxpayers most responsible for the federal tax gap?”
“This does not seem to be a place for the IRS to be using its resources,” King told Morning Tax on Monday. “There are more lucrative places to be looking.” The IRS has said that its audit process “is designed to select returns with the highest likelihood of noncompliance,” and that “the selection criteria does not include any components or factors related to the geographic location or ethnicity of the taxpayers.”
Related note: A new report from the Bipartisan Policy Center lays out how the EITC and the Child Tax Credit can be effective anti-poverty programs, but also difficult to administer — with high (if potentially overstated) improper payment rates.
Also on the schedule today: The working group on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act’s $10,000 cap on state and local deductions, formed by Democrats on House Ways and Means, is scheduled to hold its second meeting today at 4 p.m.
A related note to the SALT cap, via the Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center: “Around 4 million taxpayers per year have paid the individual Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) since 2005. Due to 2017's tax law changes, the AMT will be paid by only about 200,000 taxpayers , and will impose tax of around $5 billion in 2018, down from $31 billion in 2016.” (In previous years, most people who topped five figures in SALT charges also paid the AMT.)
FEELING THE TAX CUT? The truth is that a healthy majority of taxpayers will see their tax burden go down because of the TCJA. But a new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll found that the people themselves aren’t so sure that’s happening.
Beyond the 17 percent who believe the tax law will cut their taxes, respondents basically split evenly on three other answers — 28 percent believed they’ll pay more, 28 percent didn’t know and 27 percent think their tax burden didn’t change.
And yet keep in mind: The overall polling on TCJA has seen its share of fluctuations and has averaged out to be a net positive at times this year, though the law’s popularity has taken a dip in a couple recent polls.
DON’T MISS MORNING MONEY AT #MIGLOBAL NEXT WEEK: Just one week left to sign up for the special edition Morning Money newsletter from the Milken Institute Global Conference. POLITICO’s Ben White will detail the top conversations, major takeaways, and buzzy VIP sightings straight from one of the most influential yearly gatherings of the world’s leading minds in business, technology, government, media, philanthropy, health care, and entertainment. Sign up today .
 TAPPING OUT: French citizens have made it clear to President Emmanuel Macron and his government that they want to pay less in taxes , as Bloomberg reports. Prime Minister Edouard Philippe said there was an “exasperation” about taxes after the government held two months’ worth of town halls to get a sense of the country’s preferences, in the wake of the Yellow Vest protests started by gas tax increases. “Among the findings, valued added tax and income tax were the levies that most people listed as needing reduction. Only about 10 percent of people cited bringing back the wealth tax, though about 28 percent want higher income taxes for wealthy earners.”
STATE NEWS GONNA BE A NICE SHOWDOWN? Minnesota’s Democrat-led House rolled out a tax plan that would raise $1.2 billion in new revenues, largely from corporations, as The Minneapolis Star Tribune reported. And just like with the Democrats’ efforts to hike the gas tax, this plan faces steep opposition in the GOP-controlled state Senate. The Democrats would use the influx in revenue for new school funding, through a plan that they say would also give a tax cut to two-thirds of state tax filers. One way it does that is by expanding the standard deduction to the point that it would be used by a projected 93 percent of families. The losers under the plan would be corporations with foreign income, while the proposal would also place a 3 percent tax on capital gains above $500,000.
QUICK LINKS Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin shouldn’t stand in the way of request for Trump’s returns.
The U.S. is looking into how it could respond to a French digital tax.
Tax refund fraud is on the decline once more.
DID YOU KNOW? Zachary Levi, currently starring in the movie Shazam!, spent five seasons as the title character in NBC’s “Chuck.”

title: YouTube disables comments on hate speech hearing livestream
content:
